items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides.  Flooding is possible on the high tide at 21:00 on Sunday evening 02/01/2022, and consequent tides.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We expect high river levels to occur for the next few days.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels are now falling on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water but the lake level remains high. The weather forecast is for another drier day today and the lake level will continue to fall slowly. Areas still affected are locations around Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected. This message will be updated tomorrow, the 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have now fallen but remain high at the Llanymynech and Maesbrook river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 
At 3pm today the level at the Cae Howel gauge was 3.9m and steady. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Monday 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have fallen at the Crew Green, Montford, Welsh Bridge and Buildwas gauges. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue the alert if necessary.    
Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Monday 03/01/22 or if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight.  
Areas most at risk are farmland in the Willington, Ingleby, Barrow on Trent and Swarkestone and Bargate Lane and the access to Willington Meadows at Willington and Twyford Village access road - Church Lane at Barrow and Ingleby Lane may be affected above this level.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow on 03/01/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. River levels will remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 10am on Monday 03/01/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible later this afternoon and overnight. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Dee. Flooding remains possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington throughout today 02/01/2022. We will see river levels gradually drop throughout today. Please be aware that Townfield Lane could be cut off. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning (3/1/2022), or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of rainfall this morning, Sunday 02/01/2022. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this evening and overnight, 02/01/2022. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the lower River Ray. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue this evening and overnight (02/01/22), particularly in the Islip area. 
Isolated showers are forecast overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. Tomorrow, 03/01/2022, should then be mainly dry. River levels in the Islip area are dropping slowly, but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. River levels upstream of Lower Arncott are now below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, some of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The Flood Alert is in force for the North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton. Waves and spray are forecast to overtop coastal frontages at The North Sea coast this evening. No property flooding is expected. Flooding is possible at The North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, in particular around Hornsea between 16:00 and 18:45 on 03/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next five days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: No further significant rainfall is forecast overnight or for tomorrow, 3/1/22. We continue to monitor the situation.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the River Thame. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue this evening and overnight (02/01/22) especially in areas around Dorchester. 
Isolated showers are forecast overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. Tomorrow, 03/01/2022, should then be mainly dry. River levels in the Dorchester area are falling slowly but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. Levels upstream of Stadhampton are below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and be aware of debris and standing water that may remain on the floodplain. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but are falling steadily on the Lower Cherwell. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads remains possible this evening and overnight (02/01/22), especially in Thrupp and Kidlington areas. 
Isolated showers are forecast overnight which have the potential to be heavy at times. Tomorrow, 03/01/2022, should then be mainly dry. River levels around Thrupp and Kidlington are now within banks but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. Levels on the River Cherwell in the Oxford and Upper Heyford areas are below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and be aware of debris and standing water that may remain on the floodplain. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Welney Causeway Gauge. We expect flooding to affect the A1101 Wash Road at Welney.
This information is correct as of 15:00 on Sunday 2nd January. Lower sections of the Welney Causeway have flood water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
There are currently no issues on the Sutton Gault or Earith Causeway. 
Some further rainfall is forecast today, Sunday 2nd January, and throughout this week, therefore river levels may remain high or rise again over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Highways Teams, who will decide whether to close the roads.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Flood water is receding from the causeway at Sutton Gault, however due to the uneven surface of the road deep puddles may be encountered. Further rainfall is forecast today, Sunday 2nd January, and into next week, therefore we will closely monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to slowly fall at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, 02/01/2022 and into tomorrow 03/01/2022.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
The unsettled weather is forecast to continue into next week though we do not expect any significant totals.  River levels had fallen slightly but are now expected to rise to similar levels seen in recent days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Monday, 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are falling.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster
River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels have now fallen below levels of concern on the River Ouse. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 9:15 PM on 02/01/2022 and for the high tide forecast at 9:45 AM on the 03/01/2022. The Flood Alert will be in force for 2 hours before and after the two high water times. Forecasts suggests further Flood Alerts may need to be issued for high tide on Tuesday Morning. We will re-issue this alert with further details should forecasts continue to suggest that it is needed. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. Our incident response staff have closed relevant flood gates and have been checking defences. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please avoid flooded footpaths in the area during high tides. This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Welney Causeway river gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week. We expect flooding to affect The A1101 Wash Road at Welney. 
This information is correct as of 15:00 on Sunday 2nd January. Lower sections of the causeway have flood water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to WELNEY CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Some further rainfall is expected today, Sunday 2nd January and throughout this week, therefore whilst levels may fluctuate, they may remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

Sunday evening's tide at 23:00 on 02/01/2022 is higher than normal, with strong Westerly Force 6 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.23 m. The total forecast tide is 6.04 metres Chart Datum (2.99 mAOD) at Littlehampton, very similar to Sunday morning's tide. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Monday morning's tide at 11:30 on 03/01/2022 is forecast to be very similar and accompanied by strong winds and the same minor impacts. Wave heights are predicted to be smaller Tuesday (04/01/2022). It is likely flood risk will reduce by Wednesday (05/01/2022). We will issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 15:00 on 03/01/2022

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The Flood Alert is in force for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea. Waves and spray are forecast to overtop coastal frontages at the North Sea coast and Humber Estuary this evening. No property flooding is expected. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast and Humber Estuary, in particular around Spurn Road and Southfield Farm between 05:30 and 07:15 on Monday, 03/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next five days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The Flood Alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force. Waves and spray are forecast to overtop coastal frontages at The North Sea coast and Humber Estuary this evening. No property flooding is expected. Flooding of low lying coastal areas is possible, in particular around Kilnsea between 05:00 and 07:45 on Monday, 03/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next five days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Monday, 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.74mAOD at 13:45 on 02/01/22 and 4.74mAOD at 02:15 on 03/01/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 113 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 08:00 on 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are expected to rise on the River Thames at Trowlock Island due to todays high tide at 2.15pm   (02/01/2022) where the level is expected to be between 5.0 and 5.1m.   Therefore, flooding of low lying roads is expected. The following high tide is at 2.45am tomorrow (03/01/2022) where the level is expected to be between 5.0 and 5.1m. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads is also expected for this tide. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated this evening, 02/01/2021, or earlier if the situation changes

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast overnight tonight on 02/01/2022.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas along the coast from St Bees Head to Millom including Ravenglass and Annaside.
The highest tide level is expected at 11:00 PM on 02/01/2022 and will be accompanied by strong winds and large waves. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
The next high tide is also expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast overnight tonight on 02/01/2022.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas along the Coastline from Gretna to Silloth.
The highest tide level is expected at 11:15 PM on 02/01/2022 and will be accompanied by strong winds and large waves. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
The next high tide is also expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We are closing flood gates in the area.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas along the coast from Silloth to St Bees Head including Allonby, Maryport, Flimby, Workington, Parton and Whitehaven.
The highest tide level is expected at 11:15 PM on 02/01/2022 and will be accompanied by strong winds and large waves. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
The next high tide is also expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We are closing flood gates in the area.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast overnight tonight on 02/01/2022.
Areas most at risk include the Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
The highest tide level is expected to be at 10:45 PM on 02/01/2022 and will be accompanied by strong winds and large waves. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
The next high tide is also expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We have closed flood gates in the area.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A series of high tides is due over the next few days in the Severn Estuary. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present. The A417 at Maisemore could be closed due to flooding. Low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3m to 3.4mm at 09:30 on 03/01/22, Gloucester 3.2m to 3.6m at 09:15 on 03/01/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
This message will be updated by 10:30am on 3/1/2022.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high tides , tides will be at their highest throughout the evening at 10:45 PM on 02/01/2022.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 10:45 PM on 02/01/2022. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
The tide at 11:15 AM on 03/01/2022 is also currently forecast to be a to be at Flood alert levels ,we will send an update once this current tide has passed
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 07:00 AM on 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:

Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson and Thurnham Moss.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 07:00 AM on 03/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

As a result of high tides, tides will be at their highest during the morning at 11:15 AM on 03/01/2022.
Areas most at risk include Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss at 11:15 AM on 03/01/2022. Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
